nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the amount of tokens in existence.
nodes.name: totalSupply

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the token decimals.
nodes.name: decimals

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the token symbol.
nodes.name: symbol

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the token name.
nodes.name: name

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the bep token owner.
nodes.name: getOwner

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the amount of tokens owned by `account`.
nodes.name: balanceOf
transfer

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the remaining number of tokens that `spender` will be
allowed to spend on behalf of `owner` through {transferFrom}. This is
zero by default.
   * This value changes when {approve} or {transferFrom} are called.
nodes.name: allowance

nodes.documentation:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the caller's tokens.
   * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
   * IMPORTANT: Beware that changing an allowance with this method brings the risk
that someone may use both the old and the new allowance by unfortunate
transaction ordering. One possible solution to mitigate this race
condition is to first reduce the spender's allowance to 0 and set the
desired value afterwards:
https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/issues/20#issuecomment-263524729
   * Emits an {Approval} event.
nodes.name: approve

nodes.documentation:
@dev Moves `amount` tokens from `sender` to `recipient` using the
allowance mechanism. `amount` is then deducted from the caller's
allowance.
   * Returns a boolean value indicating whether the operation succeeded.
   * Emits a {Transfer} event.
nodes.name: transferFrom
Transfer

nodes.documentation:
@dev Emitted when the allowance of a `spender` for an `owner` is set by
a call to {approve}. `value` is the new allowance.
nodes.name: Approval

nodes.documentation:
@dev Wrappers over Solidity's arithmetic operations with added overflow
checks.
 * Arithmetic operations in Solidity wrap on overflow. This can easily result
in bugs, because programmers usually assume that an overflow raises an
error, which is the standard behavior in high level programming languages.
`SafeMath` restores this intuition by reverting the transaction when an
operation overflows.
 * Using this library instead of the unchecked operations eliminates an entire
class of bugs, so it's recommended to use it always.
nodes.name: SafeMath

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the addition of two unsigned integers, reverting on
overflow.
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `+` operator.
   * Requirements:
- Addition cannot overflow.
nodes.name: add

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the subtraction of two unsigned integers, reverting on
overflow (when the result is negative).
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `-` operator.
   * Requirements:
- Subtraction cannot overflow.
nodes.name: sub

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the subtraction of two unsigned integers, reverting with custom message on
overflow (when the result is negative).
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `-` operator.
   * Requirements:
- Subtraction cannot overflow.
nodes.name: sub

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the multiplication of two unsigned integers, reverting on
overflow.
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `*` operator.
   * Requirements:
- Multiplication cannot overflow.
nodes.name: mul

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the integer division of two unsigned integers. Reverts on
division by zero. The result is rounded towards zero.
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `/` operator. Note: this function uses a
`revert` opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity
uses an invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
   * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
nodes.name: div

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the integer division of two unsigned integers. Reverts with custom message on
division by zero. The result is rounded towards zero.
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `/` operator. Note: this function uses a
`revert` opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity
uses an invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
   * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
nodes.name: div

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the remainder of dividing two unsigned integers. (unsigned integer modulo),
Reverts when dividing by zero.
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `%` operator. This function uses a `revert`
opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity uses an
invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
   * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
nodes.name: mod

nodes.documentation:
@dev Returns the remainder of dividing two unsigned integers. (unsigned integer modulo),
Reverts with custom message when dividing by zero.
   * Counterpart to Solidity's `%` operator. This function uses a `revert`
opcode (which leaves remaining gas untouched) while Solidity uses an
invalid opcode to revert (consuming all remaining gas).
   * Requirements:
- The divisor cannot be zero.
nodes.name: mod

nodes.documentation:
@dev Contract module which provides a basic access control mechanism, where
there is an account (an owner) that can be granted exclusive access to
specific functions.
 * By default, the owner account will be the one that deploys the contract. This
can later be changed with {transferOwnership}.
 * This module is used through inheritance. It will make available the modifier
`onlyOwner`, which can be applied to your functions to restrict their use to
the owner.
nodes.name: Ownable

nodes.documentation: @dev Initializes the contract setting the deployer as the initial owner.
@dev Returns the address of the current owner.
nodes.name: owner

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Ownable: caller is not the owner"

arguments.value: Ownable: caller is not the owner

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Ownable: caller is not the owner"

nodes.documentation: @dev Throws if called by any account other than the owner.
nodes.name: onlyOwner

nodes.documentation:
@dev Leaves the contract without owner. It will not be possible to call
`onlyOwner` functions anymore. Can only be called by the current owner.
   * NOTE: Renouncing ownership will leave the contract without an owner,
thereby removing any functionality that is only available to the owner.
nodes.name: renounceOwnership

nodes.documentation:
@dev Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`).
Can only be called by the current owner.
nodes.name: transferOwnership

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "Ownable: new owner is the zero address"

arguments.value: Ownable: new owner is the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "Ownable: new owner is the zero address"

nodes.documentation: @dev Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`).
nodes.name: _transferOwnership

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the bep token owner.
nodes.name: getOwner

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the token decimals.
nodes.name: decimals

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the token symbol.
nodes.name: symbol

nodes.documentation: @dev Returns the token name.
nodes.name: name

nodes.documentation: @dev See {BEP20-totalSupply}.
nodes.name: totalSupply

nodes.documentation: @dev See {BEP20-balanceOf}.
nodes.name: balanceOf

nodes.documentation:
@dev See {BEP20-transfer}.
   * Requirements:
   * - `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.
nodes.name: transfer

nodes.documentation: @dev See {BEP20-allowance}.
nodes.name: allowance
approve

nodes.documentation:
@dev See {BEP20-transferFrom}.
   * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not
required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {BEP20};
   * Requirements:
- `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`.
- the caller must have allowance for `sender`'s tokens of at least
`amount`.
nodes.name: transferFrom

nodes.documentation:
@dev Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
   * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for
problems described in {BEP20-approve}.
   * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
   * Requirements:
   * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
nodes.name: increaseAllowance

nodes.documentation:
@dev Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.
   * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for
problems described in {BEP20-approve}.
   * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.
   * Requirements:
   * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least
`subtractedValue`.
nodes.name: decreaseAllowance

nodes.documentation:
@dev Creates `amount` tokens and assigns them to `msg.sender`, increasing
the total supply.
   * Requirements
   * - `msg.sender` must be the token owner
nodes.name: mint

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: transfer from the zero address"

arguments.value: BEP20: transfer from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: transfer from the zero address"

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: transfer to the zero address"

arguments.value: BEP20: transfer to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: transfer to the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Moves tokens `amount` from `sender` to `recipient`.
   * This is internal function is equivalent to {transfer}, and can be used to
e.g. implement automatic token fees, slashing mechanisms, etc.
   * Emits a {Transfer} event.
   * Requirements:
   * - `sender` cannot be the zero address.
- `recipient` cannot be the zero address.
- `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`.
nodes.name: _transfer

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: mint to the zero address"

arguments.value: BEP20: mint to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: mint to the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Creates `amount` tokens and assigns them to `account`, increasing
the total supply.
   * Emits a {Transfer} event with `from` set to the zero address.
   * Requirements
   * - `to` cannot be the zero address.
nodes.name: _mint

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: burn from the zero address"

arguments.value: BEP20: burn from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: burn from the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Destroys `amount` tokens from `account`, reducing the
total supply.
   * Emits a {Transfer} event with `to` set to the zero address.
   * Requirements
   * - `account` cannot be the zero address.
- `account` must have at least `amount` tokens.
nodes.name: _burn

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: approve from the zero address"

arguments.value: BEP20: approve from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: approve from the zero address"

typeDescriptions.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: approve to the zero address"

arguments.value: BEP20: approve to the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: approve to the zero address"

nodes.documentation:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the `owner`s tokens.
   * This is internal function is equivalent to `approve`, and can be used to
e.g. set automatic allowances for certain subsystems, etc.
   * Emits an {Approval} event.
   * Requirements:
   * - `owner` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` cannot be the zero address.
nodes.name: _approve
_burnFrom

attributes.type: literal_string "BEP20: transfer to the zero address"
attributes.value: BEP20: transfer to the zero address

attributes.documentation:
@dev Creates `amount` tokens and assigns them to `account`, increasing
the total supply.
   * Emits a {Transfer} event with `from` set to the zero address.
   * Requirements
   * - `to` cannot be the zero address.
attributes.name: _mint

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: mint to the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "BEP20: mint to the zero address"
attributes.value: BEP20: mint to the zero address

attributes.documentation:
@dev Destroys `amount` tokens from `account`, reducing the
total supply.
   * Emits a {Transfer} event with `to` set to the zero address.
   * Requirements
   * - `account` cannot be the zero address.
- `account` must have at least `amount` tokens.
attributes.name: _burn

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: burn from the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "BEP20: burn from the zero address"
attributes.value: BEP20: burn from the zero address

attributes.documentation:
@dev Sets `amount` as the allowance of `spender` over the `owner`s tokens.
   * This is internal function is equivalent to `approve`, and can be used to
e.g. set automatic allowances for certain subsystems, etc.
   * Emits an {Approval} event.
   * Requirements:
   * - `owner` cannot be the zero address.
- `spender` cannot be the zero address.
attributes.name: _approve

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: approve from the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "BEP20: approve from the zero address"
attributes.value: BEP20: approve from the zero address

argumentTypes.typeString: literal_string "BEP20: approve to the zero address"

attributes.type: literal_string "BEP20: approve to the zero address"
attributes.value: BEP20: approve to the zero address

attributes.name: _burnFrom

approve(address,uint256).details: See {BEP20-approve}.   * Requirements:   * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

decreaseAllowance(address,uint256).details: Atomically decreases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.   * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {BEP20-approve}.   * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.   * Requirements:   * - `spender` cannot be the zero address. - `spender` must have allowance for the caller of at least `subtractedValue`.

increaseAllowance(address,uint256).details: Atomically increases the allowance granted to `spender` by the caller.   * This is an alternative to {approve} that can be used as a mitigation for problems described in {BEP20-approve}.   * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance.   * Requirements:   * - `spender` cannot be the zero address.

mint(uint256).details: Creates `amount` tokens and assigns them to `msg.sender`, increasing the total supply.   * Requirements   * - `msg.sender` must be the token owner

owner().details: Returns the address of the current owner.

renounceOwnership().details: Leaves the contract without owner. It will not be possible to call `onlyOwner` functions anymore. Can only be called by the current owner.   * NOTE: Renouncing ownership will leave the contract without an owner, thereby removing any functionality that is only available to the owner.

transfer(address,uint256).details: See {BEP20-transfer}.   * Requirements:   * - `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - the caller must have a balance of at least `amount`.

transferFrom(address,address,uint256).details: See {BEP20-transferFrom}.   * Emits an {Approval} event indicating the updated allowance. This is not required by the EIP. See the note at the beginning of {BEP20};   * Requirements: - `sender` and `recipient` cannot be the zero address. - `sender` must have a balance of at least `amount`. - the caller must have allowance for `sender`'s tokens of at least `amount`.

transferOwnership(address).details: Transfers ownership of the contract to a new account (`newOwner`). Can only be called by the current owner.
